typeProperties.script:
source(output(
		Column_1 as string,
		Column_2 as string,
		Column_3 as string,
		Column_4 as string,
		Column_5 as string
	),
	allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	ignoreNoFilesFound: false) ~> source1
source1 sink(allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	format: 'delta',
	fileSystem: 'adftutorial',
	mergeSchema: false,
	autoCompact: false,
	optimizedWrite: false,
	vacuum: 0,
	deletable:false,
	insertable:true,
	updateable:false,
	upsertable:false,
	umask: 0022,
	preCommands: [],
	postCommands: [],
	skipDuplicateMapInputs: true,
	skipDuplicateMapOutputs: true) ~> sink1

source(output(
		movies as integer,
		Title as string,
		genresgenregenre as string,
		YEAR as short,
		Rating as short
	),
	allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	ignoreNoFilesFound: false) ~> source1
source1 filter(contains([1950, 1988, 1960], #item == YEAR)) ~> Filter1
Filter1 derive(Rating = iif(YEAR==1988,1,toInteger(Rating)),
		YEAR = iif(YEAR==1960,2021,toInteger(YEAR)),
		movies = iif(YEAR==1960,movies+1000,movies)) ~> DerivedColumn1
DerivedColumn1 alterRow(updateIf(YEAR==1988),
	insertIf(YEAR==2021),
	deleteIf(YEAR==1950)) ~> AlterRow1
AlterRow1 sink(allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	input(
		movies as integer,
		Title as string,
		genresgenregenre as string,
		YEAR as short,
		Rating as short
	),
	format: 'delta',
	fileSystem: 'adftutorial',
	mergeSchema: false,
	autoCompact: false,
	optimizedWrite: false,
	vacuum: 0,
	deletable:true,
	insertable:true,
	updateable:true,
	upsertable:false,
	keys:['movies','YEAR'],
	umask: 0022,
	preCommands: [],
	postCommands: [],
	skipDuplicateMapInputs: true,
	skipDuplicateMapOutputs: true) ~> sink1

resources.name: [concat(parameters('workspaceName'), '/1 - Create external table with SQL Dedicated')]

content.query:
/* Note: this script is filtered on a specific month. You can modify the location to read the entire dataset. */
IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT * FROM sys.external_file_formats WHERE name = 'SynapseParquetFormat')
	CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT [SynapseParquetFormat]
	WITH ( FORMAT_TYPE = PARQUET)
GO

IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT * FROM sys.external_data_sources WHERE name = 'nyctlc_azureopendatastorage_blob_core_windows_net')
	CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE [nyctlc_azureopendatastorage_blob_core_windows_net]
	WITH (
		LOCATION = 'wasbs://nyctlc@azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net',
		TYPE     = HADOOP
	)
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE nyc_tlc_yellow_trip_ext (
	[vendorID] varchar(8000),
	[tpepPickupDateTime] datetime2(7),
	[tpepDropoffDateTime] datetime2(7),
	[passengerCount] int,
	[tripDistance] float,
	[puLocationId] varchar(8000),
	[doLocationId] varchar(8000),
	[startLon] float,
	[startLat] float,
	[endLon] float,
	[endLat] float,
	[rateCodeId] int,
	[storeAndFwdFlag] varchar(8000),
	[paymentType] varchar(8000),
	[fareAmount] float,
	[extra] float,
	[mtaTax] float,
	[improvementSurcharge] varchar(8000),
	[tipAmount] float,
	[tollsAmount] float,
	[totalAmount] float
	)
	WITH (
    LOCATION = 'yellow/puYear=2014/puMonth=3/',
    -- LOCATION = 'yellow'
	DATA_SOURCE = [nyctlc_azureopendatastorage_blob_core_windows_net],
	FILE_FORMAT = [SynapseParquetFormat],
	REJECT_TYPE = VALUE,
	REJECT_VALUE = 0
	)
GO

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM nyc_tlc_yellow_trip_ext
GO

DROP EXTERNAL TABLE nyc_tlc_yellow_trip_ext

content.query:
CREATE DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL [sqlondemand]
WITH IDENTITY='SHARED ACCESS SIGNATURE',  
SECRET = 'sv=2018-03-28&ss=bf&srt=sco&sp=rl&st=2019-10-14T12%3A10%3A25Z&se=2061-12-31T12%3A10%3A00Z&sig=KlSU2ullCscyTS0An0nozEpo4tO5JAgGBvw%2FJX2lguw%3D'

CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SqlOnDemandDemo WITH (
    LOCATION = 'https://sqlondemandstorage.blob.core.windows.net',
    CREDENTIAL = sqlondemand
);
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT QuotedCsvWithHeaderFormat
WITH (  
    FORMAT_TYPE = DELIMITEDTEXT,
    FORMAT_OPTIONS ( FIELD_TERMINATOR = ',', STRING_DELIMITER = '"', FIRST_ROW = 2   )
);
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE populationExternalTable
(
    [country_code] VARCHAR (5) COLLATE Latin1_General_BIN2,
    [country_name] VARCHAR (100) COLLATE Latin1_General_BIN2,
    [year] smallint,
    [population] bigint
)
WITH (
    LOCATION = 'csv/population/population.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = sqlondemanddemo,
    FILE_FORMAT = QuotedCSVWithHeaderFormat
);

SELECT
    country_name, population
FROM populationExternalTable
WHERE
    [year] = 2019
ORDER BY
    [population] DESC;


DROP EXTERNAL TABLE populationExternalTable
DROP EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT QuotedCSVWithHeaderFormat
DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SqlOnDemandDemo
DROP DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL [sqlondemand]

content.query:
CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT [SynapseParquetFormat]
	WITH ( FORMAT_TYPE = PARQUET)

	CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE [nyctlc_azureopendatastorage_blob_core_windows_net]
	WITH (
		LOCATION   = 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/nyctlc'
	)

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE nyc_tlc_yellow_trip_ext (
	[vendorID] varchar(8000),
	[tpepPickupDateTime] datetime2(7),
	[tpepDropoffDateTime] datetime2(7),
	[passengerCount] int,
	[tripDistance] float,
	[puLocationId] varchar(8000),
	[doLocationId] varchar(8000),
	[startLon] float,
	[startLat] float,
	[endLon] float,
	[endLat] float,
	[rateCodeId] int,
	[storeAndFwdFlag] varchar(8000),
	[paymentType] varchar(8000),
	[fareAmount] float,
	[extra] float,
	[mtaTax] float,
	[improvementSurcharge] varchar(8000),
	[tipAmount] float,
	[tollsAmount] float,
	[totalAmount] float
	)
	WITH (
    LOCATION = 'yellow/puYear=2014/puMonth=3/*.parquet',
	-- LOCATION = 'yellow/puYear=*/puMonth=*/*.parquet'
	DATA_SOURCE = [nyctlc_azureopendatastorage_blob_core_windows_net],
	FILE_FORMAT = [SynapseParquetFormat]
	)
GO

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM nyc_tlc_yellow_trip_ext
GO

-- CSV file contains header row; query uses HEADER_ROW = TRUE:
SELECT 
	*
FROM OPENROWSET(
    BULK 'https://pandemicdatalake.blob.core.windows.net/public/curated/covid-19/ecdc_cases/latest/ecdc_cases.csv',
    FORMAT = 'CSV',
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0',
	HEADER_ROW = TRUE) as [r]

-- CSV file does not contain header row; query doesn't use HEADER_ROW = TRUE:
SELECT 
	*
FROM OPENROWSET(
    BULK 'https://pandemicdatalake.blob.core.windows.net/public/curated/covid-19/ecdc_cases/latest/ecdc_cases.csv',
    FORMAT = 'CSV',
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0') as [r]

-- Parquet file (schema inside):
SELECT 
    TOP 1 *
FROM  
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/censusdatacontainer/release/us_population_county/year=20*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [r]

SELECT 
	* 

-- CSV with no header row, but with schema (for two columns) specified
-- Note the 1 and 4 at the end of the two column definitions, which indicate the ordinal of the corresponding column
-- Query fails due to bad filespec
SELECT 
	* 
FROM OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://sqlondemandstorage.blob.core.windows.net/csv/population/population*.csv',
        FORMAT = 'CSV',
        FIRSTROW = 1
    )
WITH (
    [country_code] VARCHAR (5) COLLATE Latin1_General_BIN2 1,
    [population] bigint 4
) AS [r]

-- Schema specification for certain columns from Parquet file:
SELECT 
    TOP 1 *
FROM  
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/censusdatacontainer/release/us_population_county/year=20*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    )
WITH (
	[stateName] VARCHAR (50),
	[population] bigint
) AS [r]


-- Read JSON file and specifcy schema
-- Note use of lax and strict path modes
SELECT 
    TOP 1 *
FROM  
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/censusdatacontainer/release/us_population_county/year=20*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    )
WITH (
	--lax path mode samples
	[stateName] VARCHAR (50), -- this one works as column name casing is valid - it targets the same column as the next one
	[stateName_explicit_path] VARCHAR (50) '$.stateName', -- this one works as column name casing is valid
	[COUNTYNAME] VARCHAR (50), -- COUNTYname column will contain NULLs only because of wrong casing - it targets the same column as the next one
	[countyName_explicit_path] VARCHAR (50) '$.COUNTYNAME', -- COUNTYname column will contain NULLS only because of wrong casing and default path mode being lax

	--strict path mode samples
	[population] bigint 'strict $.population' -- this one works as column name casing is valid
	--,[population2] bigint 'strict $.POPULATION' -- this one fails because of wrong casing and strict path mode
)
AS [r]

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/nyctlc/yellow/puYear=*/puMonth=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [nyc]

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM
	OPENROWSET(
		BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/holidaydatacontainer/Processed/*.parquet',
		FORMAT='PARQUET'
	) AS [holidays]

SELECT
    TOP 100 *
FROM  
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/isdweatherdatacontainer/ISDWeather/year=*/month=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [weather]

SELECT
    YEAR(tpepPickupDateTime) AS current_year,
    COUNT(*) AS rides_per_year
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/nyctlc/yellow/puYear=*/puMonth=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [nyc]
WHERE nyc.filepath(1) >= '2009' AND nyc.filepath(1) <= '2019'
GROUP BY YEAR(tpepPickupDateTime)
ORDER BY 1 ASC

SELECT
    CAST([tpepPickupDateTime] AS DATE) AS [current_day],
    COUNT(*) as rides_per_day
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/nyctlc/yellow/puYear=*/puMonth=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [nyc]
WHERE nyc.filepath(1) = '2016'
GROUP BY CAST([tpepPickupDateTime] AS DATE)
ORDER BY 1 ASC

WITH taxi_rides AS
(
    SELECT
        CAST([tpepPickupDateTime] AS DATE) AS [current_day],
        COUNT(*) as rides_per_day
    FROM  
        OPENROWSET(
            BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/nyctlc/yellow/puYear=*/puMonth=*/*.parquet',
            FORMAT='PARQUET'
        ) AS [nyc]
    WHERE nyc.filepath(1) = '2016'
    GROUP BY CAST([tpepPickupDateTime] AS DATE)
),
public_holidays AS
(
    SELECT
        holidayname as holiday,
        date
    FROM
        OPENROWSET(
            BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/holidaydatacontainer/Processed/*.parquet',
            FORMAT='PARQUET'
        ) AS [holidays]
    WHERE countryorregion = 'United States' AND YEAR(date) = 2016
)
SELECT
*
FROM taxi_rides t
LEFT OUTER JOIN public_holidays p on t.current_day = p.date
ORDER BY current_day ASC

SELECT
    AVG(windspeed) AS avg_windspeed,
    MIN(windspeed) AS min_windspeed,
    MAX(windspeed) AS max_windspeed,
    AVG(temperature) AS avg_temperature,
    MIN(temperature) AS min_temperature,
    MAX(temperature) AS max_temperature,
    AVG(sealvlpressure) AS avg_sealvlpressure,
    MIN(sealvlpressure) AS min_sealvlpressure,
    MAX(sealvlpressure) AS max_sealvlpressure,
    AVG(precipdepth) AS avg_precipdepth,
    MIN(precipdepth) AS min_precipdepth,
    MAX(precipdepth) AS max_precipdepth,
    AVG(snowdepth) AS avg_snowdepth,
    MIN(snowdepth) AS min_snowdepth,
    MAX(snowdepth) AS max_snowdepth
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/isdweatherdatacontainer/ISDWeather/year=*/month=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [weather]
WHERE countryorregion = 'US' AND CAST([datetime] AS DATE) = '2016-01-23' AND stationname = 'JOHN F KENNEDY INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT'

content.query:
-- Drop database if it exists
DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS Demo
GO

-- Create new database
CREATE DATABASE [Demo];
GO

USE Demo

-- There is no credential in data surce. We are using public storage account which doesn't need a secret.
CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE AzureOpenData
WITH ( LOCATION = 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/')

DROP VIEW IF EXISTS usPopulationView;
GO

CREATE VIEW usPopulationView AS
SELECT
    *
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'censusdatacontainer/release/us_population_county/year=20*/*.parquet',
        DATA_SOURCE = 'AzureOpenData',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS uspv;

CREATE DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL SynapseSqlCredential
	WITH IDENTITY = 'SHARED ACCESS SIGNATURE',
	SECRET = 'ePmku2EGnbB0HTYPQFesiqyTKRa6lBWpzw3B89/DGvWk10WVR0kSKZsohvfgFrDtuLlpFoZi44WU+UMqp4fBLQ==';  
GO


CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SynapseSqlDataSource
WITH  (
        LOCATION ='https://bluebadgehdisa.blob.core.windows.net/bluebadgehdisc/example/data',
    	CREDENTIAL = SynapseSqlCredential
);
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT QuotedCsvWithHeaderFormat
WITH (  
     FORMAT_TYPE = DELIMITEDTEXT,
     FORMAT_OPTIONS ( FIELD_TERMINATOR = ',', STRING_DELIMITER = '"', FIRST_ROW = 2   )
);
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE MoviesDB(
    id int,
    title VARCHAR(100),
    genre VARCHAR(100),
    year SMALLINT,
    rating SMALLINT,
    rottentomato SMALLINT
)
WITH (
    LOCATION= 'MoviesDBFresh.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = SynapseSqlDataSource,
    FILE_FORMAT = QuotedCsvWithHeaderFormat
    );

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM MoviesDB

DROP EXTERNAL TABLE MoviesDB
DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SynapseSqlDataSource
DROP DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL SynapseSqlCredential
DROP EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT QuotedCsvWithHeaderFormat

CREATE DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL [sqlondemand]
--WITH IDENTITY='SHARED ACCESS SIGNATURE',  
--SECRET = 'ejm+47WgjfejH82fWDCDNE9r19U5NqfuCR3pvyG322AgaM/+qUk46chAQBgi3XxnJd7aJC/vqW/1f9+3K2Ps5Q=='
WITH IDENTITY='Managed Identity'
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SqlOnDemandDemo WITH (
    LOCATION = 'https://bluebadgehdiadls.blob.core.windows.net/bluebadgehdiadls'
    ,CREDENTIAL = sqlondemand
);
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT QuotedCsvWithHeaderFormat
WITH (  
    FORMAT_TYPE = DELIMITEDTEXT,
    FORMAT_OPTIONS ( FIELD_TERMINATOR = ',', STRING_DELIMITER = '"', FIRST_ROW = 2   )
);
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE MovieDB
(
    id int,
    title VARCHAR(100),
    genre VARCHAR(100),
    year SMALLINT,
    rating SMALLINT,
    rottentomato SMALLINT
)
WITH (
    LOCATION = 'example/data/MoviesDBFresh.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = sqlondemanddemo,
    FILE_FORMAT = QuotedCSVWithHeaderFormat
);

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM MovieDB

DROP EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT QuotedCSVWithHeaderFormat
DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SqlOnDemandDemo
DROP DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL [sqlondemand]

source:
# Creating a managed Spark table
This notebook describes how to create a managed table from Spark. 
The table is created in the Synapse warehouse folder in your primary storage account. The table will be synchronized and available in Synapse SQL Pools.
spark.Sql("CREATE TABLE cities (name STRING, population INT) USING PARQUET")
Insert a few rows into the table using a list of values.
* Retrieve values back. Click on 'Chart' below to review the visualization.
Display(spark.Sql("SELECT * FROM cities ORDER BY name"));
Drop the table. Please note the data will get deleted from the primary storage account associated with this workspace.

NewEntity.Name: Channel
NewEntity.Description: A channel is a means by which products or services are sold and/or distributed.

Columns.Name: ChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: ChannelName
Columns.Description: The name of the associated Channel.

Columns.Name: LocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: ChannelLogo
Columns.Description: A design, symbol or series of words that identifies the channel.

Columns.Name: TelephoneNumber
Columns.Description: The channel telephone number.

Columns.Name: FaxNumber
Columns.Description: The channel fax number.

Columns.Name: EmailAddress
Columns.Description: The channel email address.

Columns.Name: ChannelCommencementDate
Columns.Description: The date that the channel commenced operations.

Columns.Name: ChannelCloseDate
Columns.Description: The date that the channel was permanently closed.

Columns.Name: ChannelCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel Category.

Columns.Name: ChannelTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel Type.

Columns.Name: PartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: DunsNumber
Columns.Description: The DUNS number is a nine-digit number issued by Dun & Bradstreet and assigned to each business location in the D&B database having a unique, separate, and distinct operation to businesses for the purpose of identifying them. The number as issued is random and the digits apparently have no significance as to their issuance.

Columns.Name: DunBradstreetSingleLocationSubsidiary
Columns.Description:
There are eight (8) types of business relationships defined in D&B WorldBase:

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.

A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.

In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to NewEntity.Name: Customer
NewEntity.Description:
A customer is an individual or legal entity that has or has purchased a product or service.

A potential customer is an individual or legal entity that has the desire to acquire a product or service, the financial ability to pay for that product or service and is located in a location in which the product or service can be delivered to them.

The definition of 'customer' is of critical importance for every organization.    

It is the customer that is the focus of product planning, marketing, sales, service, reporting and analytics.    Without 'customer' there would be no need for the organization to exist since its purpose is to serve the customer and profit from that interaction.

The definition of 'customer' must be consistent with how customers exist and interact with the organization in the real world.  An artificial or conceptual definition of 'customer' that is not consistent with these two objectives is doomed to fail because the data will not be consistent with the definition and employees will not accept concepts or terms that are not consistent with what they see, know and how they interact with customers on a working basis.

Microsoft defines 'customer' to meet these objectives.    When we look out into the real world we see two dominant types of customers:  human beings and legal entities.     

Human beings are obviously male and female individuals of various ages, sex, demographics and a variety of similar dimensions that describe and define them who purchase products, good and services.    

Legal entities are those legally-defined entities such as corporations, partnerships, non-profit organizations, government organizations etc. that purchase products, goods and services.

This view of 'customer' is consistent with the real world and consistent with how employees view and interact with customers.

Of course, that is just the start of identifying, defining and understanding each type of 'customer'.     There is a great deal of detail, complexity and related data that can be used to define each type of customer to various levels of detail and different dimensions of information.

Microsoft implements these detailed concepts and related data via two distinct business area models that expand the coverage and complexity of each type of customer:

-  INDIVIDUAL CUSTOMER Business Area Model
-  LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER Business Area Model

Note:
Each of the Microsoft models - enterprise, business area or data warehouse - have a representative level of detail for the appropriate type of customer, which is a 'subset' of the total data available in the associated INDIVIDUAL CUSTOMER or LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER business area models..   Reference either of those models to expand the coverage or level of detail in each respective data model.

The actual customer implemented in each model depends upon the dominant use of customer for that industry.     

For example, in the pharmaceutical industry the customer is a legal entity, which represents another corporation, company, government organization etc. that purchases the pharmaceutical product and then distributes that product to the end-customer, which is an individual in a retail environment or a government-distribution scheme.    

For this example, the pharmaceutical models will have the legal entity customer represented but not the individual 'end customer' since that is represented in the appropriate retail industry models, which are a different offering.     

Of course, the entire set of data available for a legal entity customer is contained in the associated LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER Business Area Model.   Reference the LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER Business Area Model to incorporate additional data that may be of relevance.

In many industries both types of customers are represented since a legal entity or individual can purchase products, goods or services and enter into contracts.    For these industries, both types of customers are represented by some of the more significant or relevant data derived from the associated LEGAL ENTITY or INDIVIDUAL CUSTOMER business area models.   These models can be used to expand the scope or level of detail in any of the enterprise, business area or data warehouse models.

NewEntity.Name: Party
NewEntity.Description:
A party is an individual, organization, legal entity, social organization or business unit of interest to the business.

Party is a concept that enables individuals, organizations, legal entities, social organization and business units to be related or defined with the context of roles, events and relationships.

This enables us to 'anchor' disparate instances or implementations of each of the above to a common or singular instance of that individual, organization, legal entity, social organization or business unit.

For example, a large business has 20 customer masters that are used internally.    PARTY enables the organization to identify and define each customer as a single party and relate (cleanse and synchronize) the multiple instances of customer to a single set of customer information.

It also allows the business to look at the multiple relationships that exist among parties playing different roles over various periods of time.    

For example, a business might have a vendor who is also a customer that has employees who are also customers of the business.     A business might have employees who are also customers and whose spouse or family members are also customers.

In short, party enables the business to examine and record the real-world interactions of individuals, organizations, legal entities, social organizations and business units as they perform those many roles that characterize their activities and relationships to other parties.      Party also provides an 'anchor' upon which to resolve multiple instances or definitions of that party so the business can develop a 'single-view' of the party.

NewEntity.Name: RetailProduct
NewEntity.Description:
A product is anything that can be offered to a market that might satisfy a want or need by potential customers.    That product is the sum of all physical, psychological, symbolic, and service attributes associated with it.

There are two basic types of products:

- Tangible (physical)
- Intangible (non-physical) such as services

A service is a non-material or intangible product - such as professional consultancy, maintenance service, repair service etc.
Each product has its own benefits, application, brand name, and packaging that gives it its own identity and distinguishing characteristics.

Every business or organization has business rules that define precisely what a product is.    While we intuitively know what a product is, we must quantify that knowledge and associated business rules with consistent definitions that can be implemented within the organization in strategies and applications.

A product typically goes through five stages of development:

(1) Idea Stage - involving a thorough evaluation of the potential product

(2) Concept Stage - determines customer acceptance by testing and presentation to consumers and distribution channel members.   Specific aspects regarding quality, dependability, reliability, warranty, packaging, service, pricing, terms of sale, sales and distribution channels, advertising and promotions are evaluated.

(3) Product Development Stage - transforms the prototype product into an actual product for mass sale.   This stage requires close interaction between both marketing and manufacturing.

(4) Test Marketing Stage - may or may not be used since it is an expensive and time-consuming process.  Test marketing involves evaluating various product options and alternatives.

(5) Commercialization - It is very expensive to launch a new product so commercialization only applies to those specific products that are actually going to be sold to the market.

Products tend to be categorized as either:  Industrial goods and consumer goods

Industrial goods are used to produce other products .

Industrial goods may be further divided into:

- Raw materials
- Equipment
- Pre-built materials 
- Supplies.

Consumer goods are intended for consumption by the general public.

Consumer goods may be further divided into:

- Durable goods
- Nondurable goods
- Packaged goods

A product may be a member of a product family or product line.

A product family is a grouping of products or services that are related to each other by common function, functionality, design platform or similar characteristics.

Members of a product family frequently have many common parts and assemblies.

Product families are the highest level of grouping for forecasting, capacity planning or related functions.

Ex:
The Apple Macintosh family of products consists of the product lines:
- Mac mini
- MacBook Pro
- Mac Pro

A product line is a grouping of products that are closely related in usage, functionality or marketing characteristics.

A Product Family typically is created to address one or five functions:

1. To increase profits and not erode the sales of existing products

2. To attract additional Markets or Market Segments

3. To counter competitor's products

4. To fill a gap in an existing Product Family.

5. To promote sales of other products in the family line

Line Depth refers to the number of products in the product line.

Line consistency refers to how closely related the products are that make up the product line.

Line vulnerability refers to the percentage of sales or profits that are derived from only a few products in the product line.

Product width refers to the number of different product lines sold by a company.

Product mix refers to the total number of products sold in all product lines.

Line extension refers to the adding of a new product to a line.

"Trading up or brand leveraging" refers to adding a product of better quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

"Trading down" refers to adding a product of lesser quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

If a line of products is sold with the same brand name, this is referred to as family branding.
Strategy and decisions regarding a product line are usually incorporated in a high-level marketing plan addressing product line strategy, sales, channels, distribution channels, pricing and related issues.
A product-line manager is responsible for a product line and supervises several product managers who are responsible for individual products within the line.
Product-line managers typically have the following responsibilities:
- Expansion and composition of a product line
- Evaluate the effects of product mixes on the profitability of other items in the line
- Planning and allocation of resources to individual products in the line
A product is normally associated with a brand strategy - manufacturer, private or generic.

1. Manufacturer-  or 'national' branding in which the brand is assigned by the manufacturer of the Product.

2. Private - or 'dealer' branding in which the brand is assigned by the retailer or wholesaler of the Product.

3. Generic - in which the Product is not marked with any identification.   Generic brands are a means for manufacturers to increase profits by saving on advertising, packaging or other costs associated with manufacturer or private branding.

A brand is name, term, sign, symbol or design or a combination of these which identify the goods or services and differentiate them from those of competitors'

A Trade mark is a brand or some part of the brand that is given legal protection because it is capable of exclusive appropriation and representation.

Manufacturers can use their own brands (known as Manufacturers' brands) or brands of their distributors (Distributors' brands).

Manufacturers/ distributors use brand names for a variety of reasons ranging from simple identification purposes to having legal protection for unique features of the products from imitations.

Brands help consumers recognize certain quality parameters. In some cases, brands are just used to endow the product with unique story and character which itself can be a basis for product differentiation.

Individual brands have their own identity and the corporate or common name is not used to promote its equity.

Individual branding requires more expensive advertising and brand extensive brand creation investments.  By extension, each new brand does not benefit from the positive perceptions of earlier brands.

By contrast, family branding has several advantages.

Each new product is quickly associated with the other products and brand in terms of quality and benefits.

Reduced or eliminated time for name identification and advertising for name recognition purposes.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: ProductName
Columns.Description: The name of the Product, which normally corresponds to the 'marketing name' of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductShortDescription
Columns.Description: The short description of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductInternalName
Columns.Description:
The internal name by which a Product is known.

This normally approximates the business name by which the public identifies the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductModelName
Columns.Description: The name of the Product Model.

Columns.Name: ProductBaseName
Columns.Description: The name of the Product, which normally corresponds to the 'marketing name' of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductCodeName
Columns.Description: The internal code name by which the Product is known within the company.

Columns.Name: ProductIntendedUse
Columns.Description: The intended use of the product.

Columns.Name: IntroductionDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Product was introduced for sale.

Columns.Name: FirstDateManufactured
Columns.Description: The date that the Product was first manufactured by the Manufacturer.

Columns.Name: PlannedAbandonmentDate
Columns.Description:
The planned date to discontinue marketing the product.    

Abandonment is a component in the decline stage of the product's life cycle characterized by a reduced market demand for the product and an increased number of competing products with similar characteristics.

There are three (3) strategies for abandoning a product:

(1)  Reduced marketing and expenditures to maintain profits.

(2)  Concentrating on the strongest market segments and eliminating the weaker market segments

(3)  Maintain the marketing level until the product is discontinued.

Columns.Name: ActualAbandonmentDate
Columns.Description:
The actual date that the marketing of the product was discontinued. 

Abandonment is a component in the decline stage of the product's life cycle characterized by a reduced market demand for the product and an increased number of competing products with similar characteristics.

There are three (3) strategies for abandoning a product:

(1)  Reduced marketing and expenditures to maintain profits.

(2)  Concentrating on the strongest market segments and eliminating the weaker market segments

(3)  Maintain the marketing level until the product is discontinued.

Columns.Name: GlobalTradeItemNumber
Columns.Description:
The Global Trade Item Number (GTIN) is an identifier for trade items that was developed by GS1.

A GTIN can be assigned to only one brick.

Columns.Name: GtinName
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Product GTIN.

Columns.Name: EuropeanArticleNumber
Columns.Description:
A 13 digit barcoding standard which is a superset of the original 12-digit Universal Product Code (UPC).

aka International Article Number (abbreviation of EAN retained)

Columns.Name: UniversalProductCode
Columns.Description:
A system that identifies products by type and by manufacturer.  

A UPC consists of eleven (11) digits.  Six (6) indicate the Manufacturer and five (5) digits describe the product.

UPCs appear on product packages as bar codes, which are graphic symbols that are read by optical scanner devices.   

UPCs are assigned by the Uniform Code Council of Dayton, Ohio.

Columns.Name: GpcBrickId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a GPC Brick.

Columns.Name: ItemElectronicProductCode
Columns.Description:
EPC is the RFID version of the UPC barcode. 
EPC is intended to be used for specific product identification. However, EPC goes beyond UPC by not only identifying the product as an SKU, but also providing access to additional data about the origin and history of the specific units. 
The EPC tag itself identifies the manufacturer, product, version, and serial number. It's the serial number that takes EPC to the next level. 
This is the key to data related to specific lots/batches as well as potentially tracking the specific unit's history as it moves through the supply chain.

Columns.Name: ComponentPartIdentifier
Columns.Description: The Component / Part Identifier (CPID) is used to identify components or parts that are used in the assembly of a larger item. The CPID is part of the GS1 system of standards.

Columns.Name: PluCode
Columns.Description:
The PLU or Price Look-Up code is a 4- or 5-digit number that is primarily used on fresh produce items and will typically appear on a small sticker that is applied to an individual piece of fresh produce. 

The PLU code identifies produce items based upon the commodity, variety and size group. 

They are used by supermarkets to make check-out and inventory control easier, faster and more accurate. 

These numbers are assigned by the International Federation for Produce Standards (IFPS)

Ex: WHITE FLESH PEACHES
PLU Code = 4400

Columns.Name: ProductNetContent
Columns.Description: The standard product length.

Columns.Name: NetContentUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: StorageInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be stored.

Columns.Name: ShelfLifeDays
Columns.Description: The amount of time that a product can be stored before it can no longer be safely consumed or sold.

Columns.Name: ConsumerStorageInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be stored by the consumer.

Columns.Name: ProductShippingInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be shipped.

Columns.Name: ConsumerUsageInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be used by the consumer.

Columns.Name: HealthClaimDescription
Columns.Description: A health claim regarding the product as per regulations of the target market.

Columns.Name: MarketingMessageDescription
Columns.Description: A market message that is present on the packaging of the product.

Columns.Name: BundledProductIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether a Product is comprised of a bundle of other Products.

Columns.Name: InformationLabelText
Columns.Description: The label text that identifies the care, use, preparation and handling or the product.

Columns.Name: DescriptiveLabelText
Columns.Description: The label text that describes significant characteristics and benefits.

Columns.Name: WarningInformationText
Columns.Description: The text of the warning label, if any, appearing upon the product.

Columns.Name: GradeLabelText
Columns.Description:
The label text that identifies Product quality with letters, number or conditions.

Examples:

-  Grade A
-  Prime
-  #1

Columns.Name: GovernmentWarningLabelText
Columns.Description: The US Government (or foreign government) label text that addressing the US legal requirements of the Product.

Columns.Name: PatentNumber
Columns.Description: The patent that is associated with the Product.

Columns.Name: PatentDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Patent was granted.

Columns.Name: PatentExpirationDate
Columns.Description: The date that the patent is scheduled to expire.

Columns.Name: Trademark
Columns.Description: A 'trademark' is a brand name or brand mark that is given legal protection.

Columns.Name: ProductLogo
Columns.Description: A design, symbol or series of words that identifies the product.

Columns.Name: ProductSymbol
Columns.Description: A symbol by which the product is known.

Columns.Name: CopyrightNumber
Columns.Description:
The unique identifier (number) of the copyright granted.

A copyright is legal protection given to a work so that it can only be published or sold by the copyright holder.

Columns.Name: CopyrightDate
Columns.Description: The date that the copyright was granted.

Columns.Name: ProductLicenserName
Columns.Description: The name of the company that receives a flat fee or royalty for selling the rights to use a trademark, Patent, manufacturing right or process for the Product.

Columns.Name: EligibleForExportIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the product is eligible for export to foreign countries without restriction.

Columns.Name: ProductExportRestrictionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that exportation of the product is restricted.

Columns.Description: The period start date for which the associated restriction is in effect.

Columns.Description: The period end date for which the associated restriction is in effect.

Columns.Name: ProductExportRestrictionDescription
Columns.Description: A description or statement defining the export restriction(s) placed upon the Product.

{"entityDirectives":{"baseEntityReference":{"name":"RetailProduct","path":"RetailProduct.cdm.json/RetailProduct"},"description":"A product is anything that can be offered to a market that might satisfy a want or need by potential customers.    That product is the sum of all physical, psychological, symbolic, and service attributes associated with it.

There are two basic types of products:

- Tangible (physical)
- Intangible (non-physical) such as services

A service is a non-material or intangible product - such as professional consultancy, maintenance service, repair service etc.
Each product has its own benefits, application, brand name, and packaging that gives it its own identity and distinguishing characteristics.

Every business or organization has business rules that define precisely what a product is.    While we intuitively know what a product is, we must quantify that knowledge and associated business rules with consistent definitions that can be implemented within the organization in strategies and applications.

A product typically goes through five stages of development:

(1) Idea Stage - involving a thorough evaluation of the potential product

(2) Concept Stage - determines customer acceptance by testing and presentation to consumers and distribution channel members.   Specific aspects regarding quality, dependability, reliability, warranty, packaging, service, pricing, terms of sale, sales and distribution channels, advertising and promotions are evaluated.

(3) Product Development Stage - transforms the prototype product into an actual product for mass sale.   This stage requires close interaction between both marketing and manufacturing.

(4) Test Marketing Stage - may or may not be used since it is an expensive and time-consuming process.  Test marketing involves evaluating various product options and alternatives.

(5) Commercialization - It is very expensive to launch a new product so commercialization only applies to those specific products that are actually going to be sold to the market.

Products tend to be categorized as either:  Industrial goods and consumer goods

Industrial goods are used to produce other products .

Industrial goods may be further divided into:

- Raw materials
- Equipment
- Pre-built materials 
- Supplies.

Consumer goods are intended for consumption by the general public.

Consumer goods may be further divided into:

- Durable goods
- Nondurable goods
- Packaged goods

A product may be a member of a product family or product line.

A product family is a grouping of products or services that are related to each other by common function, functionality, design platform or similar characteristics.

Members of a product family frequently have many common parts and assemblies.

Product families are the highest level of grouping for forecasting, capacity planning or related functions.

Ex:
The Apple Macintosh family of products consists of the product lines:
- Mac mini
- MacBook Pro
- Mac Pro

A product line is a grouping of products that are closely related in usage, functionality or marketing characteristics.

A Product Family typically is created to address one or five functions:

1. To increase profits and not erode the sales of existing products

2. To attract additional Markets or Market Segments

3. To counter competitor's products

4. To fill a gap in an existing Product Family.

5. To promote sales of other products in the family line

Line Depth refers to the number of products in the product line.

Line consistency refers to how closely related the products are that make up the product line.

Line vulnerability refers to the percentage of sales or profits that are derived from only a few products in the product line.

Product width refers to the number of different product lines sold by a company.

Product mix refers to the total number of products sold in all product lines.

Line extension refers to the adding of a new product to a line.

"Trading up or brand leveraging" refers to adding a product of better quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

"Trading down" refers to adding a product of lesser quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

If a line of products is sold with the same brand name, this is referred to as family branding.
Strategy and decisions regarding a product line are usually incorporated in a high-level marketing plan addressing product line strategy, sales, channels, distribution channels, pricing and related issues.
A product-line manager is responsible for a product line and supervises several product managers who are responsible for individual products within the line.
Product-line managers typically have the following responsibilities:
- Expansion and composition of a product line
- Evaluate the effects of product mixes on the profitability of other items in the line
- Planning and allocation of resources to individual products in the line
A product is normally associated with a brand strategy - manufacturer, private or generic.

1. Manufacturer-  or 'national' branding in which the brand is assigned by the manufacturer of the Product.

2. Private - or 'dealer' branding in which the brand is assigned by the retailer or wholesaler of the Product.

3. Generic - in which the Product is not marked with any identification.   Generic brands are a means for manufacturers to increase profits by saving on advertising, packaging or other costs associated with manufacturer or private branding.

A brand is name, term, sign, symbol or design or a combination of these which identify the goods or services and differentiate them from those of competitors'

A Trade mark is a brand or some part of the brand that is given legal protection because it is capable of exclusive appropriation and representation.

Manufacturers can use their own brands (known as Manufacturers' brands) or brands of their distributors (Distributors' brands).

Manufacturers/ distributors use brand names for a variety of reasons ranging from simple identification purposes to having legal protection for unique features of the products from imitations.

Brands help consumers recognize certain quality parameters. In some cases, brands are just used to endow the product with unique story and character which itself can be a basis for product differentiation.

Individual brands have their own identity and the corporate or common name is not used to promote its equity.

Individual branding requires more expensive advertising and brand extensive brand creation investments.  By extension, each new brand does not benefit from the positive perceptions of earlier brands.

By contrast, family branding has several advantages.

Each new product is quickly associated with the other products and brand in terms of quality and benefits.

Properties.Description:
A product is anything that can be offered to a market that might satisfy a want or need by potential customers.    That product is the sum of all physical, psychological, symbolic, and service attributes associated with it.

There are two basic types of products:

- Tangible (physical)
- Intangible (non-physical) such as services

A service is a non-material or intangible product - such as professional consultancy, maintenance service, repair service etc.
Each product has its own benefits, application, brand name, and packaging that gives it its own identity and distinguishing characteristics.

Every business or organization has business rules that define precisely what a product is.    While we intuitively know what a product is, we must quantify that knowledge and associated business rules with consistent definitions that can be implemented within the organization in strategies and applications.

A product typically goes through five stages of development:

(1) Idea Stage - involving a thorough evaluation of the potential product

(2) Concept Stage - determines customer acceptance by testing and presentation to consumers and distribution channel members.   Specific aspects regarding quality, dependability, reliability, warranty, packaging, service, pricing, terms of sale, sales and distribution channels, advertising and promotions are evaluated.

(3) Product Development Stage - transforms the prototype product into an actual product for mass sale.   This stage requires close interaction between both marketing and manufacturing.

(4) Test Marketing Stage - may or may not be used since it is an expensive and time-consuming process.  Test marketing involves evaluating various product options and alternatives.

(5) Commercialization - It is very expensive to launch a new product so commercialization only applies to those specific products that are actually going to be sold to the market.

Products tend to be categorized as either:  Industrial goods and consumer goods

Industrial goods are used to produce other products .

Industrial goods may be further divided into:

- Raw materials
- Equipment
- Pre-built materials 
- Supplies.

Consumer goods are intended for consumption by the general public.

Consumer goods may be further divided into:

- Durable goods
- Nondurable goods
- Packaged goods

A product may be a member of a product family or product line.

A product family is a grouping of products or services that are related to each other by common function, functionality, design platform or similar characteristics.

Members of a product family frequently have many common parts and assemblies.

Product families are the highest level of grouping for forecasting, capacity planning or related functions.

Ex:
The Apple Macintosh family of products consists of the product lines:
- Mac mini
- MacBook Pro
- Mac Pro

A product line is a grouping of products that are closely related in usage, functionality or marketing characteristics.

A Product Family typically is created to address one or five functions:

1. To increase profits and not erode the sales of existing products

2. To attract additional Markets or Market Segments

3. To counter competitor's products

4. To fill a gap in an existing Product Family.

5. To promote sales of other products in the family line

Line Depth refers to the number of products in the product line.

Line consistency refers to how closely related the products are that make up the product line.

Line vulnerability refers to the percentage of sales or profits that are derived from only a few products in the product line.

Product width refers to the number of different product lines sold by a company.

Product mix refers to the total number of products sold in all product lines.

Line extension refers to the adding of a new product to a line.

"Trading up or brand leveraging" refers to adding a product of better quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

"Trading down" refers to adding a product of lesser quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

If a line of products is sold with the same brand name, this is referred to as family branding.
Strategy and decisions regarding a product line are usually incorporated in a high-level marketing plan addressing product line strategy, sales, channels, distribution channels, pricing and related issues.
A product-line manager is responsible for a product line and supervises several product managers who are responsible for individual products within the line.
Product-line managers typically have the following responsibilities:
- Expansion and composition of a product line
- Evaluate the effects of product mixes on the profitability of other items in the line
- Planning and allocation of resources to individual products in the line
A product is normally associated with a brand strategy - manufacturer, private or generic.

1. Manufacturer-  or 'national' branding in which the brand is assigned by the manufacturer of the Product.

2. Private - or 'dealer' branding in which the brand is assigned by the retailer or wholesaler of the Product.

3. Generic - in which the Product is not marked with any identification.   Generic brands are a means for manufacturers to increase profits by saving on advertising, packaging or other costs associated with manufacturer or private branding.

A brand is name, term, sign, symbol or design or a combination of these which identify the goods or services and differentiate them from those of competitors'

A Trade mark is a brand or some part of the brand that is given legal protection because it is capable of exclusive appropriation and representation.

Manufacturers can use their own brands (known as Manufacturers' brands) or brands of their distributors (Distributors' brands).

Manufacturers/ distributors use brand names for a variety of reasons ranging from simple identification purposes to having legal protection for unique features of the products from imitations.

Brands help consumers recognize certain quality parameters. In some cases, brands are just used to endow the product with unique story and character which itself can be a basis for product differentiation.

Individual brands have their own identity and the corporate or common name is not used to promote its equity.

Individual branding requires more expensive advertising and brand extensive brand creation investments.  By extension, each new brand does not benefit from the positive perceptions of earlier brands.

By contrast, family branding has several advantages.

Each new product is quickly associated with the other products and brand in terms of quality and benefits.

Reduced or eliminated time for name identification and advertising for name recognition purposes.

NewEntity.Name: Transaction
NewEntity.Description:
The lowest level of executable work or customer activity.

A transaction consists of one or more discrete events.

Columns.Name: TransactionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionInitiatedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp the transaction was initiated.

Columns.Name: TransactionCompletedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the transaction was completed or closed.

Columns.Name: TransactionReceivedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Transaction was received.

Columns.Name: TransactionEntryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Transaction was entered into the appropriate system for processing.

Columns.Name: TransactionConfirmationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Transaction was confirmed to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: CreditCheckTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Customer/Customer Account had a credit check in regard to the Transaction amount.

Columns.Name: RequestedDeliveryDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Customer/Customer Account requested delivery of the items.

Columns.Name: CommittedDeliveryDate
Columns.Description: The date committed to the Customer/Customer Account for delivery of the items.

Columns.Name: ActualDeliveryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The actual timestamp of delivery of the items to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: DeliveryConfirmationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that confirmation of the delivery or Shipment was made to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: TransactionAmount
Columns.Description:
The amount associated with the transaction.

Ex:
Refund = 'amount'
Credit = 'amount'

Columns.Name: ShipmentToName
Columns.Description: The name of the ship-to party.

Columns.Name: ShipmentToLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: TransactionConfirmationNumber
Columns.Description: The transaction confirmation number provided to confirm that the transaction was executed.

Columns.Name: IdentificationCheckedIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the individual's identification was checked for any requirements for the transaction. For example: The individual is 21 years of age or older in order to purchase alcohol products.

Columns.Name: IdentificationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the identification.

Columns.Name: TotalRetailPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The total list price value of the Transaction products = (list price per unit product price)x(quantity ordered) for each line item.

Columns.Name: TotalAdjustmentPercentage
Columns.Description: The total percentage of adjustment(s) applied to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TotalAdjustmentAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of adjustments applied to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TotalTransactionSalesPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The total actual price value of the transaction item(s) = (actual selling price per unit product price)x(quantity) for each line item.

Columns.Name: TotalShippingChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of shipping charge associated with the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionTotalTaxAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of all taxes applied to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionRoundingAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of rounding applied to the transaction. This is typically done when the payment method is cash and the total invoice amount is rounded to an amount that is payable using legal tender. (e.g. 1 cent coin is no longer in legal circulation.)

Columns.Name: TransactionTotalInvoicedAmount
Columns.Description: The total invoiced amount to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: TotalCommissionsPayableAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of commissions payable and due in regard to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: SplitCommissionsIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the commissions are to be split between two or more employees.

Columns.Name: RequestedShipmentCarrierName
Columns.Description: The name of the Carrier for the Shipment requested by the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: AlternateCarrierAcceptableIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that an alternate Carrier of the Shipment would be acceptable to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: ShipCompleteIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Transaction item(s) are only to be shipped when complete - no partial shipments.

Columns.Name: AcknowledgementRequiredIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that an acknowledgement  to the Customer/Customer Account is required for the Transaction.

Columns.Name: ExpediteTransactionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Transaction is to be expedited.

Columns.Name: DropShipmentIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Transaction item(s) are to be drop shipped.

Columns.Name: ActualShipmentCarrierName
Columns.Description: The Carrier of the Shipment.

Columns.Name: TotalWeight
Columns.Description: The total weight of the Transaction item(s).

Columns.Name: TotalFreightChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The total freight charges amount.

Columns.Name: UnitOfMeasureId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: EarliestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The earliest timestamp that the transaction should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: LatestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The latest timestamp that the transaction should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: DeliveryInstructions
Columns.Description: Instructions related to the delivery of the Transaction item(s).

Columns.Name: CustomerCreditCheckNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Transaction credit check.

Columns.Name: MessageToCustomer
Columns.Description: A message to the Customer/Customer Account regarding the Transaction.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: PurchasingChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: SalesChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: DistributionChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: PromotionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Promotion.

Columns.Name: TransactionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Type.

Columns.Name: BillingCycleId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Billing Cycle.

Columns.Name: MerchantId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Merchant.

Columns.Name: CustomerIdentificationMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a customer identification method.

Columns.Name: TransactionClassificationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Transaction Classification.

Columns.Name: TransactionProcessingStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Processing Status.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: TransactionExecutionMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Execution Type.

Columns.Name: TransactionPriorityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Priority.

Columns.Name: TransactionTaxStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Tax Status.

Columns.Name: WebPageUrl
Columns.Description:
The unique address of any Web document.

The URL consists of:
Type of file (ex: http://)
Domain name (ex: www. name.com)
Path or directory to file (ex: /notes/internet)
Name of file (...name.html)

Columns.Name: SessionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Session.

Columns.Name: WorkstationSessionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Workstation Session.

Columns.Name: PointOfSaleId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a POS.

Columns.Name: StoreId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Store.

Columns.Name: WarehouseId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Warehouse.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: TransactionNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Transaction.

Columns.Name: ShipmentMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipment Method.

Columns.Name: DeviceId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Device.

Columns.Name: SoftwareProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a software product.

Columns.Name: SoftwareProductVersionNumber
Columns.Description: The version number of the software product.

Columns.Name: ApprovedByEmployeeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Employee.

Columns.Name: PromotionOfferId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Promotion Offer. The Promotion Offer ID is unique to each account or party that is offered to.

Columns.Name: LoyaltyCardId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Loyalty Card.

Properties.Description:
The lowest level of executable work or customer activity.

A transaction consists of one or more discrete events.

NewEntity.Name: TransactionLineItem
NewEntity.Description: The components of an Transaction broken down by Product and Quantity, one per line item.

Columns.Name: TransactionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionLineItemId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier that identifies the Transaction Line Item.

Columns.Name: TransactionLineItemStartTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp the transaction line item was started.

Columns.Name: TransactionLineItemCompletedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the transaction line item was completed or closed.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: ItemSku
Columns.Description: The Stock Keeping Unit identifier, which is typically used for inventory-related activities.

Columns.Name: UniversalProductCode
Columns.Description:
A system that identifies products by type and by manufacturer.  

A UPC consists of eleven (11) digits.  Six (6) indicate the Manufacturer and five (5) digits describe the product.

UPCs appear on product packages as bar codes, which are graphic symbols that are read by optical scanner devices.   

UPCs are assigned by the Uniform Code Council of Dayton, Ohio.

Columns.Name: Quantity
Columns.Description: The quantity of Product ordered on the transaction line item.

Columns.Name: UnitOfMeasureId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: PreorderIndicator
Columns.Description: The quantity of Line Items returned.

Columns.Name: ProductListPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The current per unit list price of the Transaction Line Item products.

Columns.Name: TransactionProductPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The price of the product as applicable to the Transaction Line Item.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: FreeSampleIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that product was provided as a free sample.

Columns.Name: TotalTransactionLineItemAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of line item charges related to the quantity of products sold at the actual selling price less rebates and discounts.

Columns.Name: TotalTransactionSalesPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of line item charges including all rebates and discount and taxes.

Columns.Name: TransactionLineEntryMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Line Entry Method.

Columns.Name: TransactionLineItemScanTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp the transaction line item was scanned.

Columns.Name: PosDeviceId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a POS Device.

Columns.Name: ScaleUsedIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the scale was used to determine the weight of the item.

Columns.Name: ScaleMeasuredItemWeight
Columns.Description: The weight of the line item on the scale for pricing purposes.

Columns.Name: WeightUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ScaleQuantity
Columns.Description: The quantity of Product ordered placed on the scale.

Columns.Name: TransactionLineVolume
Columns.Description: The volume of the line item for pricing purposes.

Columns.Name: VolumeUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ProductPriceOverrideIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the standard product price amount from the price list has been overridden.

Columns.Name: ProductPriceAdjustmentAmount
Columns.Description: The per product unit adjustment amount applied to each product unit.

Columns.Name: ProductPriceAdjustmentPercentage
Columns.Description: The per product unit adjustment percentage applied to each product unit.

Columns.Name: TotalLineItemAdjustmentAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of adjustment for all line items.

Columns.Name: LineItemNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Line Item.

Columns.Name: QuantityBooked
Columns.Description: The quantity of Product booked.

Columns.Name: QuantityBilled
Columns.Description: The quantity billed.

Columns.Name: QuantityBacklog
Columns.Description: The quantity on backlog.

Columns.Name: AcceptedQuantity
Columns.Description: The quantity of Line Item products accepted.

Columns.Name: QuantityCancelled
Columns.Description: The quantity of Line Items cancelled.

Columns.Name: QuantityReturned
Columns.Description: The quantity of Line Items returned.

Columns.Name: BookedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The booked date of the Line Items.

Columns.Name: BilledTimestamp
Columns.Description: The billed date of the Line Items.

Columns.Name: CancelledTimestamp
Columns.Description: The date  and time that Line Items were cancelled.

Columns.Name: ReturnedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The date that Line Items were returned.

Columns.Name: CommittedShipmentTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp committed for shipment of the Line Item.

Columns.Name: RequestedDeliveryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp for delivery of the Line Item requested by the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: CommittedDeliveryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp committed for delivery of the Line Item.

Columns.Name: CommittedAvailableForPickupTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp committed for the Line Item to be available for pickup.

Columns.Name: PlannedPickTimestamp
Columns.Description: The planned inventory pick timestamp for the Line Items.

Columns.Name: ActualPickTimestamp
Columns.Description: The actual inventory pick timestamp for the Line Items.

Columns.Name: PlannedShipmentTimestamp
Columns.Description: The planned shipment timestamp of the Line Items.

Columns.Name: ActualShipmentTimestamp
Columns.Description: The actual shipment timestamp of the Line Items.

Columns.Name: PlannedDeliveryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The planned delivery timestamp of the Line Items.

Columns.Name: ActualDeliveryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The actual delivery timestamp of the line items.

Columns.Name: DeliveryConfirmationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the shipment/delivery confirmation notice was sent to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: ShipmentChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The amount the customer has been charged for shipping.

Columns.Name: ShipmentCostAmount
Columns.Description: The amount that the shipping cost.

Columns.Name: PickPackageCostAmount
Columns.Description: The cost associated with picking a packing the item. This amount is normally included in the overall shipment cost.

Columns.Name: ShippingLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: ShipmentMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipment Method.

Columns.Name: DropShipLineItemIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Line Item(s) are to be drop shipped.

Columns.Name: WaybillNumber
Columns.Description: The shipment waybill number.

Columns.Name: TareWeight
Columns.Description: The weight of the line items excluding packaging.

Columns.Name: NetWeight
Columns.Description: The weight of the line items including packaging.

Columns.Name: ShipCompleteIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Transaction item(s) are only to be shipped when complete - no partial shipments.

Columns.Name: EarliestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The earliest timestamp that the transaction should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: LatestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The latest timestamp that the transaction should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: ReturnOfTransactionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction.

Columns.Name: ReturnOfTransactionLineItemId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier that identifies the Transaction Line Item.

Columns.Name: ReturnToStockIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Line Item(s) were returned to stock.

Columns.Name: ReturnToStoreIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Line Item(s) were returned to the store from which they were purchased.

Columns.Name: ApprovedByEmployeeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Employee.

Columns.Name: SalesChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: DistributionChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: TransactionLineItemTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Line Item Type.

Columns.Name: FuelPumpId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Fuel Pump.

Columns.Name: BuyClassId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Buy Class.

Columns.Name: PromotionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Promotion.

Columns.Name: PharmacyId
Columns.Description: The number assigned by the NABP to identify the pharmacy

Columns.Name: PharmacyTransactionId
Columns.Description: The number assigned by the Pharmacy to identify prescription fulfillment.

Columns.Name: PromotionOfferId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Promotion Offer. The Promotion Offer ID is unique to each account or party that is offered to.
